conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process, analyze changes in internal energy and work done during each process.
State A: Temperature is 200K and pressure is 10^5 Pa.
State B: Process from state A to B involves a change in volume, use ideal gas law to relate pressure and volume.
Ideal gas law: PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is moles, R is gas constant, T is temperature.
At state A, PA = 10^5 Pa and TA = 200 K.
At state B, find pressure PB and volume VB using ideal gas law: PB = nRTB/VB.
Substitute values to get PB = (n)(R)(200 K)/VB.
State C: Process from state B to C involves a change in volume, use ideal gas law to relate pressure and volume.
At state B, PB = 10^5 Pa and TB = 200 K.
At state C, find pressure PC and volume VC using ideal gas law: PC = nRTC/VC.
Substitute values to get PC = (n)(R)(200 K)/VC.
Work done by gas on surroundings during cyclic process is difference in internal energy at state A and state C.
Internal energy at state A: UA = nRTA.
Internal energy at state C: UC = nRTC.
Work done by gas: W = UC - UA.
The work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process is 0.
